Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2012 06:25PM borjo wrote: I googled it already, and not only found some good articles, but several people who posted their own experience along with research.  Apparently the body knows how to shut down safely during fasting, so it slows down and they don't absorb the chemicals.  But cancer cells don't recognize the instructions to slow down, so burn as usual.  And since chemo is supposed to work better on cancer because cancer cells grow faster, and this makes the difference in growth rate between "normal" cells and cancer cells even more pronouced, it seems to make sense.  I still worry about things that you can't find in google.

Posts.Content: borjo wrote: I am starting 6 rounds of chemo next week, and a friend swears that fasting a few days before and after the treatment really reduces side-effects. She says she came out of her treatment with no long-term side effects at all (other than hair loss).  Has anybody else tried this?  Does anybody know anything more about it?  I have done some searches, but it would be nice to know first-hand.
